About the team
The Evernote Design team is the creative collective responsible for producing a seamless and delightful user experience, from sign-up to the thousandth note. We work collaboratively with cross-functional teams to define and deliver product experiences that enhance people's lives at work and at play.

Why growth design is special
Growth is an exciting and emergent field. We'd be lying if we said we fully understood it ourselves… but then again, that is just the thing. To be truly successful at it, you have to be willing to admit you don't know. You have to want to keep learning. Growth experimentation is an alchemical process that calls upon art, psychology, reason, the scientific method, and on some occasions a little luck and magic doesn't hurt either. Relentless creativity and cheerful optimism will take you far. One of our designers wrote a great post about it. Give it a read! The Product Designer's Guide to Growth.

What you'll do
As a Product Designer on the Growth Experiments team, you will work with an incredible group of designers, developers, product managers, and data analysts to identify and execute on a wide range of strategic tactics for getting people more engaged with Evernote. You will craft memorable onboarding experiences, optimize monetization flows, and reimagine the UX of pivotal moments in a customer's journey. Together, we will design tons of growth experiments, and we will move numbers.
Be the voice in the room that always puts the user first—constantly looking for ways to accomplish business objectives through experiences that are delightful and meaningful for real people.
Carry ideas from inception through development and multiple rounds of iteration.
Define and execute A/B tests and multivariate experiment designs, flowcharts, prototypes, UI mockups, technical specs, and production assets.
Translate quantitative data and qualitative insights into creative ideas and informed design decisions.
Drive a high level of visual fidelity across products.
Provide and solicit actionable feedback to move designs forward.
Balance a large volume of design initiatives at high velocity and keep your head straight.
Learn. All the time, every day.
What you've done
Experience designing engaging user experiences for both web and native apps.
Proficiency in user-centered design thinking methodologies and rapid iterative experimentation.
Experience with prototype designs in lo- and hi-fidelity, and know when to do which.
A proven track-record for shipping high quality experiences.
2+ years of relevant product experience.
B.A., B.S. or M.A. in design, HCI, or equivalent experience.
Who you are
Able to learn quickly and recognize on a deep level that everything is changeable and everything can be better (possess a growth mindset)

Unafraid to debate and share your point of view while being receptive to others.
Eager to take initiative and ownership of projects.
Highly visual with passion for UI design and typography.
A ninja. We're not just being cute here. To succeed in this role you must be quick, clever, resourceful, nimble, focused, and above all, 100% committed to the mission.

San Francisco

Full-time

In 1954, in Columbus, Indiana, Eero Saarinen designed a bank with glass walls, no offices, and a completely open floor plan. It was surrounded by trees; the furniture was made by Herman Miller; the lobby flooring was thick, rustic brick. The bank was built with transparency and community at its core.
Since 1954, a lot of things have happened — Saarinen’s bank branch is now a conference center, people increasingly live on the internet, and it’s hard to think of a single bank that still applies design thinking to their product.
Mercury is building a bank for startups. We believe building a bank in 2021 revolves around thoughtful design, and we’re looking to add a visual designer to our team to help.
You will:
Create a unified visual language for Mercury across mediums, including marketing pages, web and mobile apps, emails, print, online ads, billboards, and marketing ephemera
Create graphics for digital formats, like our website, and physical objects, like our debit cards, tote bags, and tea packages
Use visual design to express our values and product philosophy
Work on projects with a wide scope, from minute interactions and animations to whole pages of the website
Take prosaic moments and turn them into something special with elegant design
You should:
Have a certain wild visual flair
Think about design systems, not just individual pages or embellishments
Have experience designing visuals for web, mobile, and print
Have an interest in learning about and working on product design
Understand how to create clean layouts with a strong visual structure and hierarchy
Believe in the beauty of utility and function
Be able to tell complex stories with simple visuals
Pull from a wide range of aesthetic references and be able to synthesize them into a single cohesive style
Understand Mercury’s brand, voice, and aesthetic, and how they can be expressed through your design
Be able to articulate and debate the reasoning behind your design decisions
Have a love for language

Challenge.
We’re shaking up one of the least innovative, most powerful industries around, eliminating pain points faced by every startup, and filling a crucial missing piece in the tech ecosystem.
Building a bank from the ground up is a big project; the product is complex and cannot break, there are stringent regulations, and we’ll have to outcompete some of the largest, most entrenched corporations in the world. But overcoming these challenges means we’ll have built something that lasts.
Impact.
Working on a lean, self-motivated team means autonomy, broad experience across projects, and seeing your contributions directly shape the product and impact users.
You’ll work on pieces of the product where you’ll make foundational decisions; starting from scratch requires careful thought, and your design choices will serve as the bedrock of future development.
Quality.
Design is a fundamental differentiator between us and the rest of the market, so we invest heavily in making a quality product and will give you the resources to build something beautiful.
We try to think hard about how to make features that users love; see our blog post on our date picker for an example. Our goal is to be proud of what we’ve crafted.
